A container is partially filled with water of density <math alttext="rho sub w" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mi>w</mi></msub></mstyle></math>. A sphere with density <math alttext="rho sub s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mi>s</mi></msub></mstyle></math> and radius <math alttext="r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>r</mi></math> is held under the water by a string with negligible mass which is attached to the bottom of the container, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. (a) The dot in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> represents the sphere when the sphere is at rest attached to the string. Draw and label arrows that represent the forces (not components) that are exerted on the sphere. Each force must be represented by a distinct arrow starting on, and pointing away from, the dot. Forces that point in the same direction must be drawn side by side.

(b) The string is cut, and the sphere rises upward in the water. Drag forces from the water are negligible. Starting with Newton’s second law, derive an expression for the acceleration of the sphere immediately after the string is cut. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="rho sub s" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mi>s</mi></msub></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="rho sub w" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mi>w</mi></msub></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="r" overflow="scroll"><mi>r</mi></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate. Begin your derivation by writing a fundamental physics principle or an equation from the reference booklet.

(c) On the axes shown in Figure <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>, sketch a graph of the velocity of the sphere as a function of the vertical position of the sphere in the container starting from the moment the string is cut until the top of the sphere reaches <math alttext="y equals h" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>h</mi></math>.

The sphere rises to the surface of the water, traveling the distance <math alttext="h" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>h</mi></math> in time <math alttext="t sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math>. The sphere travels a distance <math alttext="h" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>h</mi></math> through the liquid in a time <math alttext="t sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mstyle></math>.(d) Justify why <math alttext="t sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math> is greater than <math alttext="t sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mstyle></math>.
